text:
Locations of London: Barbican Centre.
Built between 1970 and 1980, the Barbican Centre is one of the greatest examples of Brutalist architecture in the world and home to Cass Business School’s graduation ceremony taking place this Monday. We can’t think of a more prestigious location at the heart of London for our students to graduate!
.
.
#barbican #graduation #cass #cassbusinessschool #businessschool #graduates #brutalism #prestigious #heart #heartoflondon #london #celebration #citygrad
linkedText: Locations of London: Barbican Centre. Built between 1970 and 1980, the Barbican Centre is one of the greatest examples of Brutalist architecture in the world and home to Cass Business School’s graduation ceremony taking place this Monday. We can’t think of a more prestigious location at the heart of London for our students to graduate! . . @barbican @graduation @cass @cassbusinessschool @businessschool @graduates @brutalism @prestigious @heart @heartoflondon @london @celebration @citygrad

text:
We’re delighted to announce that the Duchess of Sussex will be at City, University of London next week where she will be making her first appearance as Patron of The Association of Commonwealth Universities to meet with ACU staff and many Commonwealth students. 
City is one of 500 members of The ACU.
#ACU #commonwealth #highereducation #university #duchessofsussex #london #cityuniversityoflondon
linkedText: We’re delighted to announce that the Duchess of Sussex will be at City, University of London next week where she will be making her first appearance as Patron of The Association of Commonwealth Universities to meet with ACU staff and many Commonwealth students. text:
City’s Professor Tim Lang of the Centre for Food Policy and a number of other world-leading experts have been working to establish the first scientific targets for a healthy diet from sustainable food systems.
Read more about the research here: 
www.thelancet.com/commissions/EAT
•Photo by Sonja Vermeulen📷

text: Today we feed two birds with one scone, combining a #marblemonday with an exclusive from our exhibition The story of City: life, learning, legacy. This impressive financial ledger from 1891 had no key and remained locked for many years (which has kept it well preserved). Recently unlocked and on display in our exhibition, the selected page shows the honoraria paid to each architect for entering the competition to submit a design for the Mountford Building. Do you know who won? #city125 #cityuniversityoflondon #archives #marbledmonday
linkedText: Today we feed two birds with one scone, combining a @marblemonday with an exclusive from our exhibition The story of City: life, learning, legacy. This impressive financial ledger from 1891 had no key and remained locked for many years (which has kept it well preserved). Recently unlocked and on display in our exhibition, the selected page shows the honoraria paid to each architect for entering the competition to submit a design for the Mountford Building. Do you know who won? @city125 @cityuniversityoflondon @archives @marbledmonday

text: Taken at 7:50 this morning at the intersection of Pentonville Road and Upper Street. At this time last week it was still dark out. The days are slowly but surely getting longer. #londonisopen #urbansunrise #earlymornings #springwatch #nofilter

text:
Have you visited our Exhibition The Story of City : life, learning and legacy? Today we share an online exclusive.

The proposed Northampton Institute Key Plan of Site Shewing Positions of Station Points for Perspectives. 4th August 1892.

This plan shows the awkward triangular site that the building would occupy. The site was donated by William Compton, the fourth Marquis of Northampton and his son, William, Earl Compton. An article written at the time in The Builder notes “The site was a difficult one to treat, owing to its shape…though apart from this it is a fine site, with good frontages in each direction.” The blue area shows vacant land, the pink area was yet to be acquired, and on the yellow area was tenanted at the start of the building process.
linkedText:
Have you visited our Exhibition The Story of City : life, learning and legacy? Today we share an online exclusive.

The proposed Northampton Institute Key Plan of Site Shewing Positions of Station Points for Perspectives. 4th August 1892.

This plan shows the awkward triangular site that the building would occupy. The site was donated by William Compton, the fourth Marquis of Northampton and his son, William, Earl Compton. An article written at the time in The Builder notes “The site was a difficult one to treat, owing to its shape…though apart from this it is a fine site, with good frontages in each direction.” The blue area shows vacant land, the pink area was yet to be acquired, and on the yellow area was tenanted at the start of the building process.

text: To celebrate 125 years of City, we present our first exhibition, The Story of City: Life, learning and legacy. On display are documents and objects which tell a story about the origins of City, then known as the Northampton Institute. You can view the exhibition in University Building Pavilion until the end of the year.
linkedText: To celebrate 125 years of City, we present our first exhibition, The Story of City: Life, learning and legacy. On display are documents and objects which tell a story about the origins of City, then known as the Northampton Institute. You can view the exhibition in University Building Pavilion until the end of the year.

text:
Welcome to the Launch Lab Lounge - our favourite place to hangout. We love it for it’s 
versatility. It’s great for meetings, getting your head down, eating lunch, workshops & even fun events like puppy therapy! Our next intake of startups will be in Feb 2019. Link in bio to application, deadline is tomorrow 6pm!

text: Meet Launch Lab residents Elena & Sabine who cofounded @tryatec , the online marketplace for listing, discovering & renting the greatest technology gadgets. Link in bio to application.

text: Today as part of Frazzled Founders week where we provide some much needed down time activities for our founders, we had puppy therapy! Three adorable pups from @mrbsproperwalks came to visit us, so we could help raise money for @sbtrescue and Cinque Ports Rescue, huge thank you to Rowena and Amos who were fantastic! If you're interested in joining the City Launch Lab & enjoying such activities as these, the deadline for February's intake is 29 Jan. Application link is in the bio!

text:
Applications to City Launch Lab are now open! If you’re a City Student or Graduate 
who needs help to launch & scale your business, then you’re eligible to apply. Free 
office space, access to mentors & a fantastic community of other start-ups awaits you. Link to more info in bio. Deadline is 29 Jan 2019.
